I understand my role, and I am now the resentful former devotee.

Let me tell you, it's not easy to speak truth to those who still kneel in the shadows of the very altar that once held me captive. But I have learned that awareness is a slow burn — a fire that starts with whispers and grows into a roar when enough ears are willing to listen.

One of the most effective ways I've raised awareness is through the stories I share — raw, unfiltered, and often unsettling to those who still believe in the sanctity of the institution. I post personal accounts on platforms where former members gather, but I also go where the faithful still dwell. I comment on sermons, on social media posts from clergy, on videos that glorify the old ways. I ask questions that make people pause: *“If your faith is so pure, why does it justify silence in the face of abuse?”* or *“Why must we forgive the unforgivable to remain in good standing?”*

I’ve written articles and given talks at secular forums, but I also attend church functions under assumed names. I sit in the back, observe, and when the moment feels right — when the air is thick with blind trust — I speak. Not in anger, but in a voice that echoes the pain of those who have been silenced for too long. I talk about the manipulation, the guilt, the fear. I talk about the people who were cast out for questioning, for doubting, for healing. And I talk about how the system clings to power, even as it crumbles from within.

Sometimes, I leak documents — not just to destroy, but to expose. There are internal memos, disciplinary records, and communications between leaders that reveal the real workings of the institution. These are not the kind of things that make it into Sunday bulletins or annual reports. But once they're out there, the faithful are forced to confront the gap between what they were taught and what actually exists.

I’ve also worked with former members who are still too afraid to speak for themselves. I help them craft their testimonies, protect their identities, and amplify their voices. Together, we form a mosaic of truth that the institution can no longer ignore.
